awd_titl_txt: Melting of compressed iron-alloys by monitoring atomic dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
The Earth's core is 16% of the planet by volume. It is composed primarily of iron, but includes a quantity of lighter elements whose presence, but not identity, is inferred from geophysical measurements. The core consists of a solid inner section surrounded by a convecting, liquid outer layer. It creates Earth's magnetic field, protecting the planet from space weather events such as solar flares, and provides the heat for plate tectonics as the liquid core freezes. The core begins approximately 2900 km below the Earth's surface, making it difficult to determine its exact composition and temperature profile, so scientists rely on laboratory experiments and an evolving model to infer core characteristics. Under this NSF award, the PI is developing a new application of the Mössbauer effect utilizing synchrotron X-radiation to populate data points on the melting curve of an iron-nickel alloy, a primary component of Earth's core.  This project will provide support and training for students at the undergraduate and graduate level, who will be trained in experimental research utilizing national synchtrotron radiation facilities.

Laser heated diamond anvil cells, time-resolved synchrotron Mössbauer spectroscopy, x-ray diffraction and a recently developed fast temperature readout spectrometer are used to carry out these measurements. X-ray photons at one of iron's Mössbauer resonant energies are focused on the sample in a laser heated diamond anvil cell, and when melting occurs, the characteristic Mössbauer signal abruptly decreases. Thus, time-resolved Mössbauer spectroscopy provides an excellent diagnostic for the first melt formed in the sample chamber. These outcomes will represent a significant step towards understanding the melting of iron-rich alloys at conditions of terrestrial-type planetary cores. This is in addition to applying a new method that measures the atomic dynamics to the effort of determining melting at high-pressures. The proposed research agenda offers a unique synergy and training ground for the involved students to apply state-of-the-art experimental techniques at multiple facilities, including advanced radiation sources at national facilities, to scientific problems in the area of high-pressure melting investigations of Earth materials, an active area of research.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit. Seismological and cosmochemical observations indicate that the main constituent in Earth's core is iron, which is thought to be alloyed with ~5-10 wt% nickel and some light elements (e.g. S, Si, O, C, H) to explain the positive offset in density of pure iron compared to seismic inferences. As Earth's core consists of a solid inner region surrounded by a liquid outer core, the melting temperature of iron at high-pressure provides an important reference point for the temperature distribution at that interface, affecting a number of important geophysical quantities, such as: the geodynamo, heat flow across the core-mantle boundary region (CMB), the temperature gradient within the CMB thermal boundary layer, phase relations and expected seismic wave speeds of candidate phases in the core and CMB region. More specifically, the melting point of iron at the boundary between the liquid outer core and solid inner core provides an upper bound of the temperature at that interface, because studies thus far indicate that most plausible outer core liquids coexist with corresponding inner core alloy solids at or below the melting point of pure iron. Melting studies of iron at high-pressures have been performed by shock-compression, resistive- and laser-heating in diamond anvil cells using visual observations, synchrotron x-ray diffraction or absorption, synchrotron Mossbauer spectroscopy, and theoretical methods. However, the melting curve of iron with respect to its alloys has been uncertain, especially at pressures above 70 GPa. The major goals of this project are to develop a multi-technique approach to detect melting at high-pressures and apply this approach to iron-alloys relevant to Earth's core. 

With this NSF award, we have determined the equation of state of iron-nickel-silicon alloys to pressures of around 170 GPa. Using our newly developed multi-technique approach, the high-pressure melting and solid phase relations of Fe0.8Ni0.1Si0.1(Fe-11wt%Ni-5.3wt%Si), a composition compatible with recent estimates for the cores of Earth and Mercury. We find that the addition of 10 mol% Si to Fe0.9Ni0.1 reduces melting temperatures by about 250 K at low pressures (<60 GPa) and flattens the hcp-fcc phase boundary. Extrapolating our results, we constrain the location of the hcp-fcc-liquid quasi-triple point at 147 +/- 14 GPa and 3140 +/- 90 K, which implies a melting temperature reduction of 500 K compared with Fe0.9Ni0.1. The results demonstrate the advantages of combining complementary experimental techniques in investigations of melting under extreme conditions and have implications for the temperature of Earth's core-mantle boundary. 

Broader Impacts. Throughout the award period, the involved graduate students Rachel Morrison and Vasilije Dobrosavljevic were exposed to and applied state-of-the-art experimental techniques at multiple facilities (Caltech and national synchrotron facilities). The PI and Vasilije Dobrosavljevic worked with colleagues at the Advanced Photon Source of Argonne National Laboratory to develop a multi-technique approach for detecting melting of iron-alloys at high pressures that combines results from two independent in-situ probes: synchrotron Mossbauer spectroscopy, sensitive to dynamics of solid-bound iron atoms (a technique developed by the PI to detect melting), and x-ray diffraction, sensitive to long-range crystalline order. Both students presented their latest findings at COMPRES annual meetings and Fall Meetings of the American Geophysical Union, as well as at other conferences. Rachel earned her Ph.D. from Caltech in 2018 and is currently a geophysicist at ExxonMobil. Vasilije Dobrosavljevic earned his Ph.D. from Caltech in 2022 and was awarded a Postdoctoral Fellowship at Carnegie's Earth and Planets Laboratory, where he is currently conducting research related to planetary interiors.
